author: Handyman
title: A fantastic innovation
body:
Previous lengthy waits and male pride fueled a reluctance to attend the A&E department for a small but deep cut on my arm.  
However, as there was a high risk of infection. A first aider friend advised me to present myself at the Minor Injuries Unit, QEUH, Glasgow, a medical department I had never heard of before.  
A&E was as busy as I expected it to be, and I felt that I had been awarded special VIP status in bypassing the numerous patients awaiting triage by heading to straight to the MIU.  
Within minutes of arrival I was welcomed and registered by Karen, a physiotherapist enthusiastically expanding her expertise to include the treatment of minor injuries under the relaxed and confident tutelage of Elaine.  
Within an hour I was bandaged and heading home, my wound having been x-rayed, cleaned and treated efficiently, painlessly and without further trauma.  
Add a tetanus booster to the visit and the entire process was streamlined to the point of perfection.  
While each and every staff member I met was caring and helpful it was clear that Karen and Elaine share a passion for their vocation and they obviously love helping and healing people.  
Their devotion to delivering proficient healthcare and the successful and smooth operation of their unit was evident in their considerate approach and conduct throughout my treatment.  
They explained their procedures to me in clear and concise terms, ensuring that I left with full knowledge of what to expect as my injury healed, detailing my responsibilities towards re-dressing and protecting the wound, reassuringly including the option to return without hesitation should any difficulties arise.  
They were polite, courteous and friendly; treating me with unbiased compassion and sympathy, undeserved given the stupidity I'd demonstrated in sustaining my injury. They are an absolute credit to the NHS, the Hospital and the MIU to which they clearly enjoy feeling an integral part.  
The unit is undoubtedly a place where they feel totally comfortable and proud to work, operating at the top of their game in offering the best treatment and care for their patients, whom they regard more as guests. I'm privileged to have benefitted from their skills and I hope they feel personally rewarded every day, knowing how invaluable their commitment is.  
I thank them for choosing medicine as their profession.  
The existence of the Minor Injuries Unit is a God-send, and I saw for myself in real time its provision of tangible relief to the pressure on the main A&E department.  
If I hadn't been convinced to go to the MIU, I would almost certainly have avoided hospital and insisted upon treating the wound myself, which could have led to serious complications, ultimately costing the Health Service more time and money.  
I liken the MIU to the medical version of a drive-thru, it's a fantastic innovation.  
Genius status applies to those who devised its inception, and countless blessings are owed to those making it work.  
Having eliminated the requirement for triage, it's the perfect solution for the timeous assessment and treatment of minor cases.  
Given the regular press reports illustrating the stress that A&E departments countrywide are under, surely the MUI initiative has to be included as a strategy in easing the strain on every buckling casualty dept, getting eejits like me in and out the door asap?  
Given the high quality of care and benefit to patients and the NHS I might have expected the MIU to be situated within a purpose built, state of the art facility, well signposted and easily locatable beside the main A&E Department, instead of a makeshift portacabin hidden within hospital grounds.  
There is currently little or no visual directional guidance, which is surprising considering that it a part of Scotland's flagship hospital.  
That aside, the temporary building was impeccably clean and I had no doubt that I was in a safe and sterile environment, operating in full compliance with guidelines to mitigate Covid 19 risks.  
I concluded that the unit must be relatively new and ready for growth and development. With medical personnel such as my own carers at the point of patient contact, the QEUH MIU can only flourish as it is upgraded.  
I don't plan to injure myself again anytime soon, but if I do I know that because there are people like Elaine and Karen ready to assist at a moments notice,  
I won't have any hesitation in seeking professional medical treatment from the onset, rather than procrastinating.  
Thank You QEUH MIU, I hope to see you expand and enhance in the future, you truly are the crutch that your A&E department so desperately needs.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Gurveen
title: Inconsistent and unhelpful support from the Home Treatment Team
body:
I took my father to A&E due to his presentation of low mood, anxiety and suicidal ideation. It was difficult to get my father to go to A&E to access the support he required and took great encouragement due to his anxiety despite him desperately wanting the support. At A&E, my father was referred to the Crisis Team for a medication review. Following this review, we began to receive intervention from the Hounslow Home Treatment Team who provided almost daily home visits.  
Our initial home visit was with a Mental Health Nurse. Their attitude towards my father we found to be completely inappropriate, unprofessional and inexcusable. They made extremely unhelpful and inappropriate comments about my father’s situation and said that they felt sorry for his daughters for having to deal with my father. My father is already struggling with thoughts of guilt of being a burden to others around him, and this comment alongside the general behaviour and attitude towards my father only further contributed to my father’s anxiety. My father was shaking after this interaction. When I and my father mentioned that the behaviour and comments were unhelpful they responded by saying they knew they were direct and they had gotten this feedback from other people before, but that’s the way they work. I am extremely concerned about his behaviour and these comments, as these are potentially triggering for individuals who are already experiencing a mental health crisis.  
In the following visits, my father shared how despite trying the new medication suggested by the doctor, his anxiety is not improving and that he is struggling everyday, especially in the mornings, with chest pain, shaking hands, headaches, and pains elsewhere in the body. Several of the nurses who attended home visits suggested that my father should be prescribed medication due to the severity of his anxiety. He was continuously told that his concerns and opinions would be passed on to the doctor in time for his next medication review. However, on the day of his next medication review, he was not prescribed any change in medication and the nurse who came to visit him on the evening after his medication review cited reasons of some medications being addictive.  
We explained to the nurse that my father has previously taken similar medication in the past on a PRN basis. I showed the nurse a box of the medication issued from 2021 and my father still had 1 tablet remaining. Once the nurse had left, my father presented as severely anxious. He presented with laboured breathing, shaking and shared concerns of increased heart rate, headache - like my head is in a vice - and severe chest pains, due to the contradicting information regarding medication. It is as if he is given false hope during these visits, only for these moments of hope that he is clinging onto to be taken away.  
We told the nurse that we would be making a complaint and that I would be speaking to the doctor the next morning. The doctor then arranged for my father to be prescribed the medication twice a day. They shared that my father should be on this medication due to the severity of his anxiety and that if this medication does not help, they will put my father back on an alternative as this helped my father previously but was stopped by his GP.  
My father was feeling more optimistic as he was now being heard and being involved in his care. The medication was helpful in managing his anxiety. We asked for no home visits over the weekend as we had a guest staying over and my father did not want the guest to be aware of his anxiety. Without the visits and my father taking his medication, he was able to manage his anxiety well and he was starting to feel better.  
[Very unhappy with 'Seeing the whole me']  
  
However, following this period, when the team returned for a home visit, the nurse once again said that my father should no longer be on the medication despite only taking it for a week, as it is addictive. My father shared that the doctor had specifically said that he should be on a specific dose each day, but he was only given a lower dose by the nurse who visited. They said that the team would bring more the next day but they only brought him 7 tablets. I then had to call the doctor the day after to ascertain whether my father was still prescribed the medication and the dosage he should be on. They shared that my father should still be on the higher dose. I shared my frustrations with the doctor on the call. They were apologetic and agreed to stopping home visits for a while due to the toll it was having on my father.  
[Very unhappy with 'Being listened to']  
[Very unhappy with 'Involved in decisions']  
  
We felt frustrated that our concerns were not being heard. My father having to open up and share his mental health difficulties every day is a difficult process and leaves him feeling heavy. This exhausting process of reliving and recalling his difficulties everyday is made worse when following this, he is not provided the support discussed during these visits. There have been numerous occasions when I have been called by my father when I am at work, and when I have returned from work and he is in extreme distress due to his interactions with the crisis team. This is a service which is aimed at providing support to individuals experiencing a mental health crisis. Instead of providing supportive and empathetic care, they are making my father’s condition worse. A crisis team should be offering a more empathetic and supportive approach due to the level of risk presented by their patients.The team must be consistent with their guidance on what they tell their patients as this confusion can be triggering and distressing and further add to their difficulties in their moments of crisis.

author: Still_smiling
title: Mixed experience in the emergency department
body:
I was recently admitted by ambulance with suspected neutropenic sepsis, I’m currently having anti-cancer treatment (chemotherapy) for breast cancer. On arrival I was taken to resus, staff were concerned about my risk of infection due to possible neutropenia and tried to isolate me away from other patients, which was much appreciated.  
One of the doctors was excellent. He explained about neutropenic sepsis. I explained I had a card which details that I should have certain antibiotics immediately (the paramedics were informed of this too). They confirmed they could see this on system.  
They struggled to get a cannula in due to my poor venous access, I did have a PICC line however, this was not to be used. Unfortunately after several attempts it was unsuccessful and he went to get an ultrasound machine to help. This was in use. therefore I had to wait.  
They sought help from another doctor who was fantastic. Very reassuring as I was extremely nervous about needing to get the line in for treatment. There were several attempts with the ultrasound machine however, finally successful. The medical staff offered constant reassurance. They were able to take off some bloods for sending to the lab but were unable to obtain blood cultures peripherally. My PICC line wasn’t cultured in A&E either.  
I believe IV fluids were prescribed but I did not get these prior to IV antibiotics.  
I was advised later whilst in ward that my temperature was raised in the Emergency department but I was not offered paracetamol until at least 7:00 pm (more than an hour after arrival). I had advised the team I felt hot and sweaty.  
Antibiotics were prescribed and I had to wait I believe over an hour for these to be administered from prescription, in total approx 3 hours from being in the ambulance.  
I could hear the nursing staff saying they were unsure how it was made up, and they were looking on the computer to gain this information. I also heard from nursing staff that this was one that people can react to. The nursing staff advised one of the antibiotics takes a while to dissolve therefore this was the delay, however I don’t understand why the other antibiotic wasn’t administered while waiting.  
The night shift staff came on duty. Gary and Leah were fantastic, they created an instantly calm environment and Gary provided reassurance regarding the antibiotics and how I would be monitored.  
In my opinion there are learning opportunities here.  
1. It would be helpful to source another ultrasound machine for the department  
2. The awareness of the importance of prompt delivery of antibiotics in suspected neutropenic septic patients  
3. Creating an environment that’s reassuring  
4. Prompt delivery of IV fluids and medication such as paracetamol in someone who is pyrexial.  
5. Prompt blood cultures as this increased hospital stay by 1 night as the results were not known  
I have fed this back to oncology team also to gain an understanding of why I went to Emergency department and not straight to ward 32. I am of the understanding this was due to the chest pain I was experiencing.

author: skynh95
title: Disappointing experience
body: I wish that may experience so far was as positive as the others mentioned. But I am honestly dreading my next appointment. This is my first pregnancy and I leave the community midwives feeling deflated. Between waiting an hour for an appointment that they had no record of, assumptions that I am meant to know when and where to get a Whooping cough vaccine or provide a urine sample and a midwife furiously typing away on her computer giving me little eye contact, the whole experience so far has felt unenjoyable. I just want to give birth to this baby and be done the process.

author: Frustrated gmouth patient
title: Unable to get an appointment
body:
I find the care provided by my GP surgery to be awful.  
I called again today for a follow up appointment - yet again, told to call back next week, no appointments available.  
It took 4 weeks to finally get my appointment to then have bloods taken 2 weeks ago. Now I’m trying to get the follow up appointment the doctor suggested. I was told to call back next week, or have a phone call appointment Thursday evening. They will then decide if I can have a face to face appointment. Reception staff cannot give me a face to face appointment.  
This happened for last appointment and I got no phone call after doctors call. 1 week later I had to call them to ask what had happened. Today I called at 8:30am to be told I’m number 16 in queue. Then all appointments are full for today.  
I am off work on sick just now, and getting nowhere at all. I need to go back to work, but I am no further forward. I have very high blood pressure, menopause symptoms, neuropathic pain and insomnia.  
Why is this practice so bad? It is a joke. Can I move to another practice ? The other local practice is also full.

readBy.name: Office of Michelle Thomson, MSP for Falkirk East

author: carinahb87
title: Friendly and efficient care
body: I had excellent care from the staff at the Cardiology Outpatient Department concerning the wound check. I have always found them to be very friendly and efficient.

readBy.name: Office of Michelle Thomson, MSP for Falkirk East

author: NanaG
title: An absolute credit to the service and her profession
body: I saw staff nurse Michelle today for my baseline scan. She was an absolute credit to the service and her profession. There are many staff within healthcare that are skilled and competent in their work however Michelle obviously has an innate ability in working with people, making me feel at ease while providing care which helped me understand what was going on. She was respectful and personable while maintaining a professional approach and I only hope that the rest of the staff team I come across are as warm, understanding and supportive during the rest of my journey.

title: Phone calls
body: When you have cancer and you're waiting on news from the hospital, hours and days seem to pass very slowly. When you get missed calls from the hospital number you become desperate to know who has phoned you and why. If staff leave no name or number then it becomes a nightmare to find out who has called you so that you can contact them when you are able to. So, would you please train staff to leave a name and number and some indication of when they can be contacted. No further details should be provided due to patient confidentiality, but a name and number would greatly help to reduce anxiety and frustration caused by missed calls from the hospital number.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: shambles to get an appointment
body: It is pathetic that you have to ring up at 8 o clock to try and get an appointment even if it is not urgent and can be a couple of weeks away.  This is the state of the NHS bring back the turn up at the surgery book in between 10 and 11  like it used to be.

title: Poor surgery
body: Had a x ray and bloods was told they had the results and make an appointment got an appointment for a month later 6th May today had another text no one available rescheduled for 25th May rang them was told practice manager would call me back today and had no call. They are not bother about their patients

author: Adrian22
title: I am really glad this service is available for people
body:
I lost my Mum on Boxing day 2021. On top of this I had Covid, so I had a lot to manage as I was also isolating.  
The service provided me with lots of other points of contact which I followed up.  
My contact agreed to call me on a weekly basis. This really helped me in the first 2-3 months. She was extremely kind and understanding and the call was something I could look forward to.  
I took on board some good advice, so I am really glad this service is available for people.

author: Rikqs54
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: One of the best
body:
We were first allocated Mr Phillips in February. Mr Phillips is extremely knowledgeable of mental health issues / legislation / terminology and was able to not only work hard on my husbands behalf but also explain to us in a manner which made it easy to understand. He was able to break things down and use simplified terminology.  
Mr Phillips has a calming manner, even when I am frustrated he has been able to diffuse the situation and make me see the correct way to go about things.  
I hope you realise just what you have got in an employee like Mr Phillips. He has knowledge, understanding, is able to be empathetic but completely professional.  
Let's just say, he's a good man! One of the best.

author: vulpeculacp58
title: Amazing at their jobs
body:
Amazing care and support from Banbridge community midwifes- Marie and Ghillian.  
So lovely and professional. Amazing at their jobs.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: spring83
title: They are so compassionate and knowledgeable
body: I have undergone fertility treatment with the clinic several times. The treatments were not successful, however the team are incredible. They always go above and beyond to help, listen and learn. It is such a lonely time going through fertility treatment, but the team have really helped me by understanding and listening. They are so compassionate and knowledgeable.

author: TonyS
title: Waiting to get Mental Health Support
body: My mental health deteriorated. I was not sleeping or eating properly but unfortunately when looking for help or support the waiting time is very lengthy. I am now being seen by someone regularly who has been amazing and we are working to get me the help I need but it did take a year to get to this stage.

author: MMRostrevor3
title: Kind and efficient care in A&E
body:
At the end of April whilst doing a bit of outdoor DIY, I fell in my partners garden around 7:30pm and injured my shoulder. It was pretty bad and I made my way to A&E in Craigavon.  
From the moment I entered the dept I was looked after so well without exception. The lady on reception immediately took me through and a nurse sent me straight to X-ray. Once X-rayed the radiology team ( so kind and patient ) took me back into the nurse where they put me on a trolley and in no time I was given pain relief to breath in and my dislocated shoulder was fixed and put in a sling. All in all I was in the dept no longer than 90 mins. The dept was extremely busy yet the staff managed me so efficiently and with great kindness. I was well informed at every step and my expectations were well managed.  
The nurses and doctor attending me were extremely professional and took time to explain everything , I am very grateful for their prompt and excellent care.  
Today I spoke on the phone with SR Hagan in Fracture Clinic. She was helpful in it signposting me to Physio , and when I called Physio , I spoke with Stephen who took the time to explain to me the care plan , the timeframe and what to expect going forward. He confirmed my appt in May and helped provide me with reassurance and confidence in the next steps.  
I really want to convey my appreciation and hope this is shared with those involved, their excellent work does not go unnoticed !

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mercury88
title: Unhappy with mental health support
body: My husbands worker went off sick we wasn’t assigned anyone else. We have to constantly ring to chase up medication that then arrives days late. The manager is never in to speak to neither is the receptionist. From our experience this has been a very poor service for someone who is mentally struggling. The doctor that sees my husband just rushes through the appointment and mid conversation they said we’ve got to go. Now he’s been left with no worker and no idea where his medication is coming from.

author: Ovalfrog
title: Great service on a Bank Holiday Monday
body: Contacted the Downe as my son was not able to swallow properly and hadn't eaten or drank that day. We spoke to a doctor and he said bring him in. We were seen assessed and away with antibiotics for tonsillitis within 20 minutes. Great service on a Bank Holiday Monday.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: PatriA
title: This hospital and the team is 10/10
body:
I had a small skin surgery today in a very awkward place, so I was really worried and embarrassed, but the nurses and the doctors made me feel very comfortable and valued.  
The team is just great at this department. I can’t remember the names of the doctors and nurses, but how they treated me is just amazing.  
One of the friendly doctors walked me along to the operation theatre and then he asked what music station I like and put the music on.  
Nurses are very caring and been keep asking me how I feel etc. Plus the hospital porters been very helpful too. Helped me to find the right department and walked me there.  
This hospital and the team is 10/10.

author: pyxisxn98
title: Felt very privileged
body: I feel very privileged to have been able to do rehab again. It was of a very high standard, very professional and very organised. It ran very smoothly and the girls very quickly put you at your ease. It gives you a lot of confidence, which is sometimes lost through having a respitory illness. There is nothing that could have made it better for me... Except I wish I could do it on a regular basis.

author: funnywg63
title: Very positive place
body: Very welcoming, nice place to come and felt part of a group. A very positive place to learn and setting. A good group of people and tuition.

author: julietym36
title: Given me confidence
body: I have learned alot more about my condition than before. And you have given me more confidence than I had before. Yes I will still feel abit worried when I get a cold, but hopefully will be able to cope more.

author: lotionsh48
title: My parent's diagnosis with dementia.
body:
Of course when you realise one of your parents has been diagnosed with something like dementia you are devastated. You are scared, anxious and the road ahead looks very daunting. It did not come as a surprise as we had been seeing the signs for a while but still it takes a while to accept once the diagnosis has been formally given.  
It was good to know we were not alone, with excellent support mechanisms, including an excellent social worker. There were issues with a care package not being available and being caught between two trust areas.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Tudor81
title: What I liked most was that she looked at the entire picture
body:
Great service provided by one of the health service staff, Saba.  
We had an appointment with the Speech and Language Therapist in the community for my baby. She was very professional, always came in time, ready to listen. She had a professional attitude, very friendly and optimistic. What I liked most was that she looked on the entire picture to understand the medical problem and provided reassurance to my partner and myself.  
I hope I will meet more professional people like her, as is what NHS need it.

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: IreneW
title: The NHS at its very best
body:
I would like to offer my gratitude for the treatment I have had over a number of months from the respiratory department of the RAH.  
I visited my GP feeling breathless and with weakness and heaviness in my legs. After various blood tests and examinations I was referred for a chest X-ray.  
It did not show up what was expected (fluid in the lungs) but something else which was unexplained which was a real worry. After this I was referred to the respiratory department at the RAH who arranged a CT scan which was carried out within 5 days of my referral. After this I saw Dr Gravil who explained that the result was inconclusive but she was convinced it was not cancer which was a huge relief. Dr Gravil referred me for pulmonary function tests, which were normal and a bronchoscopy (quite unpleasant) and another scan, which still didn’t give me an answer to my continuing symptoms.  
By this time Dr Gravil had retired and I was under the care of Dr Grieve, who suggested another X-ray and scan - both of which were still inconclusive. After consulting with his colleagues who examined the scan images I was referred for a PET scan which showed that there was now some improvement in the markings in my lungs.  
Then the decision - I was diagnosed with cryptogenic organising pneumonia and the treatment was steroids.  
Not ever having heard of this condition I looked up the details and was pleased to learn that it was not life threatening and was likely to improve with the steroids.  
For some months I gradually reduced the dose of steroids and am now off them completely. My symptoms have gone. I feel well, I can climb my stairs without stopping in the middle (which at my worst I couldn’t do), attend to my large garden and keep up with my teenaged grandson!  
I would like to offer my thanks for all the help I received in discovering what was wrong with me - the not giving up, finding what the problem was and providing the treatment which had been successful.  
All this shows the NHS at its very best - the knowledge and expertise of our local medical staff and their persistence in trying to find answers for me which were far from simple.

author: sagittariusje66
title: Worrying staff attitude for people with a long term condition
body:
There was an incident in the ward. A patient was being rude to a nurse, or HCA, and they shouted back. At one point both of them were screaming and swearing at each other. Other staff present were laughing or trying to calm the patient down. No-one spoke to the nurse. No-one tried to reassure other patients. The patient may have been rude, but she was on the dialysis machine and was not a risk to anyone. Staff should have stepped away or de-escalated, instead of shouting back. It could have gone horribly wrong.  
It was very unpleasant and scary to witness. It made me feel unsafe and added to a very chaotic atmosphere in the ward. I feel, just because we are long term patients with no other option, staff can be nonchalant.  
The nurses often advise us that we need to wait patiently for our transport, and that this is not a five star service. Most people are very thankful for NHS. It is rude to talk like this or be impatient with people who do not speak English. Many women have not had the opportunity to learn English; being impatient with them is not going to change it.

author: Kazzie74
title: Very caring staff
body: I had an appointment at the gynaecology clinic at Grantham hospital and was a bit worried about it. On arrival, all the staff including reception went out of their way to put me at ease. They were friendly and considerate to my dignity and comfort. My procedure was thoroughly explained and I was given time to talk and ask questions, not feeling rushed at all. Thank you to all the staff there, you're doing a fantastic job.

author: SadieE
title: Excellent service from the Menopause Nurse Specialist
body: I asked for advice/support with regards to the long waiting time to be seen at the Menopause Clinic. Nurse Sutherland contacted me immediately via phone and spoke with me in depth. I am so grateful to her for speaking directly with me and sorting out my issue. She gave me excellent information, was friendly and supportive and arranged for my prescription to be organised by the end of the week. Thank you so much.

author: jobbyjazz
title: I feel 1000 times better than when I arrived
body:
Made to feel very welcome on arrival. Very friendly and helpful staff. Excellent facilities and very clean. Well structured day, organised but not military like. Great food.  
I feel 1000 times better than when I arrived. Would visit again if it didn't mean relapsing!

author: yankeezt86
title: Daunting at first but I quickly felt welcome
body:
I came in a complete mess, after 2-3 days I started to heal. I hadn't eaten properly for 5 months and am now happily eating 3 meals a day.  
The staff have been exceptional, they cannot do enough for you and no problem is too big. The accommodation is exemplary.  
Would recommend more funding for similar institutions and services such as the Forward Trust. Absolutely faultless, and I am now on my 8th day and feel like a different person, the person I should be. Nothing negative to say, an absolute compliment to the detox service. I wish I had done it years ago. It was daunting at first but quickly felt welcome.

author: Kathas
title: Urology Department
body:
Excellent care from nurses and doctors for myself and husband who both have cancer and other geological issues. Cannot be faulted.  
Administration, though, is atrocious & inefficient. Patients do not expect when finally tracking down the person who left them a message after several days, no one else was able to help or find out what it was about, to informed that they had just been doing a favour for a friend A but that another person called B should be able to help the next day. Does no one keep a record of messages left and received? Eventually the biopsy was cancelled an hour before starting as the blood tests needed had not been done despite the patient querying this during one of the many calls.

author: mckeown1990
title: Helpful groups and activities
body: I was very nervous when I first came but was made to feel welcome and settled in well. Found the staff very helpful and kind and my peers all helped me out. Everyone helps and supports each other. Food has been good and varied. Care was really good. Groups were helpful and activities were varied such as the gardening which I enjoyed.

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: my stay on the trauma ward
body: An ambulance picked me up from my sister’s home last week after I had a bad fall. The ambulance arrived within 30 minutes and brought me over to the emergency department. I stayed here for a night as it was extremely busy and they seemed to be understaffed. Once I arrived onto the trauma ward I felt a bit more relaxed. Although now I find the wards quiet noisy as there are a lot of patients on it and it’s more difficult to rest. The foods been alright, I like the soup.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Nell123
title: Amazing network of friendly staff members
body:
I was admitted last week for a ten day detox stay.  
As you can imagine, I was really nervous and pretty, anxious, but I was greeted with such an amazing network of friendly staff members.  
During my stay here at Dame Carol, I was guided through various sessions and groups to be able to find myself again and to realise why I have made the decision to abstain from my alcohol misuse.  
I'm going home soon and I'm really sad to leave.  
I want to thank everyone for all your guidance, help, a shoulder to cry on and for listening.

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: no issues with the ward
body: I’ve had no issues what so ever with anything on this ward. The nurses and doctors have been so caring and thoughtful towards me. I’ve been using the iPads to face time my family, it’s been great as it can be very boring being in the hospital. The foods been okay, I haven’t ate too much of it as I don’t really like the selection.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kathas
title: Renal Transplant Team
body: Excellent care and support from the whole team, cannot be faulted.

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: nurses are amazing
body: I came to lurgan in March through the emergency department from the royal, the ambulance came straight away as soon as I was ready. The food is great, and I honestly could not say anything other than good about all the staff at lurgan. They are so chatty and I love being able to have a conversation as it really passes the day. My room is so lovely and clean. The only complaint I do have is when I was at the other end of the ward in bed 6, there were 5 beds in a 4 bed ward and I was just very uncomfortable as it was very packed.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: meal portions too big
body:
I arrived in Lurgan 2 or 3 weeks ago and I was brought over through the emergency department from Craigavon. The ambulance did not take very long at all.  
The food is alright although I have no appetite and the portions are way too big I would prefer if I was able to choose the size of the meal as it’s such a waste of food.  
The nurses are very helpful and friendly and the room is very clean. I get very lonely sometimes and get extremely bored of watching TV and doing crosswords.  
When I press the buzzer when I need someone or have to go to the toilet, it can take the nurses a while although I already know they are under a lot of pressure so this doesn’t bother me too much.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Aoiyf36
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I know I am in safe hands
body:
I had a consultation with my local GP and less than an hour after phoning them about my increasing difficulty with breathing during any activity, even just getting dressed. The thought it would be best for me to be admitted into Craigavon area hospital so that they are able to investigate the possibility of blood clots or lung cancer. My GP was great as they were able to contact them to expect me.  
My sister drove me to hospital and I arrived at about 1:30pm. I was seen immediately by a lovely nurse and was examined by the doctor.  
Within 8 hours I was thoroughly examined, had an X-ray, ECG and CT scan. Their opinion was that I was suffering a blood clot.  
I am preparing to go into surgery, the staff are very kind and they have been very supportive and are always keeping my family up-to-date with all that is happening. Everyone I have seen has been so attentive and kind. To have been given so much attention and investigation in such a short time and be diagnosed, in my opinion, quite amazing and I cannot praise everyone who saw me too highly. My heartfelt thanks to everyone concerned. I have great trust with the doctors and nurses here in Craigavon and know that I am in safe hands

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Niamhh1
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: helpful nurses
body: I have been in lurgan for 3 weeks, the ambulance took around 20 minutes from Craigavon. The food is okay. The nurses are very nice and so helpful, I couldn’t say a bad word about them. My side room is so clean, the cleaning staff do a wonderful job.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Serialhunter9
title: Helpful wheelchair service
body: I have been diagnosed with osteoarthritis in both my legs. When I phoned about my wheelchair I thought the staff was quite helpful and got the chair I wanted which I'm quite happy with. It will help make my everyday life much easier now. Thank you so so much Westmarc, I'm very happy with the service you provided me with, thanks millions.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: deltatk76
title: Birth of my son
body: I gave birth to my son in April at the Borders General Hospital and had a wonderful experience. Despite how challenging labour and delivery can be, especially for me as a first time mum, I was provided with excellent care, compassion and encouragement from the maternity staff. My son and I had to stay in hospital for a few extra days, and in that time our continued care by the midwifery and Special Care and Baby Unit Team was superb and we were so well looked after. I also benefitted from additional breastfeeding support which has made the transition to home so much easier. All staff are incredibly knowledgeable and dedicated to their work and we are so grateful to them! They have truly provided a best start in life for our wee one.

author: GB54
title: Kind and caring ambulance service
body:
Dad took unwell in March and the ambulance crew were fantastic. Yes they were busy but when they arrived they were great they took such good care of him. They were kind and caring to dad and my mum who he helps look after.  
We had to wait outside at A/E before we could get in but they continued to look after him and were so kind. I know the pressure everyone is under at the moment but just want to say thank you

author: Mrs Cam
title: Exceptional staff
body:
I had an ilioscopy . The staff in the Endoscopy Suite, from reception to recovery and procedure, we’re all fantastic, compassionate and very professional.  
They definitely made the whole experience much easier.

author: EM xo xo xo
title: Fabulous out of hours care
body:
On Monday I had to contact NHS 24 directly due to my own GP surgery not being open. The telephone operator and the charge nurse I spoke to were very kind and lovely. I had a bad chest infection and my care was treated appropriately and effectively and I was passed over to the doctor. This doctor Claire was lovely and was keen to see me down in Douglas Street.  
I was seen immediately and had my obs took from a very kind clinical support worker (Kimberley). I was then examined by the doctor and was then sent away with the necessary treatment that has made such a difference already. From phoning NHS 24 to my appointment at OOH it was such a fast process and I feel so lucky to have received such fab care from lovely individuals. I believe all the ladies I spoke to on Monday deserve the recognition because it’s not very often they get it. It certainly made a massive difference to my day!

author: Chippie87
title: Airedale Hospital Day Surgery
body:
After almost a 2yr wait (understandable due to non urgent procedure & covid related issues) I was booked in to day surgery for a diagnostic laparoscopy. Attended a pre op assessment, answered many in depth questions about my health. Explained I had had some cardiac tests over the last few years which despite a small leaky valve issue the Cardio department had written to my GP with no cause for concern. As the assessment nurse could not see any of this on their files, I suggested they contact Cardio to check out all was well with my heart health. I attended for my operation 5 days later, met the anaesthetist who, after many of the same pre op questions and looking at my records said they would be very, very worried about anaesthetising me due to a heart problem (he showed me some paperwork) from my last cardio dept. scan. My operation was cancelled there & then after a 2 year wait. Why was this heart issue not picked up at the pre op as I specifically asked them to check? Why was I not informed by cardio of this apparently serious event in my health ? This total lack of organisation resulted in massive waste of NHS time and money/resources and a missed opportunity for someone else who'd perhaps been waiting years for surgery to receive treatment in my place on the day.  
This has caused huge distress to me after a long, stressful and painful wait for treatment and I left the hospital in tears, feeling sick and frankly angry....not at the team on the morning who were lovely but the lack of care/feedback/attention to important details pre op. I now also have the worry about a heart issue detailed in my records I was not aware of and more waits for treatment. I am a realist, (perfection does not exist in any organisation) I would have been understanding if my non urgent op had been cancelled on the day due to emergency/unforeseen staff problems.  
This type of event should not be happening to any patient due to admin issues. I have contacted the Cardiology dept and PALS, left messages Answerphones and await responses.

author: Baillie_12woof
title: Skin cancer in back
body: Got Ah small section off skin cancer cut out my back by David the Surgeon,he was 1st class n really put me at ease with the 30 minute op, theyre we’re 2 nurses on hand to help out -Lynda n Megan ,overall was really pleased with the 1st class service that ah received from the 3 mentioned, ah really worrying time but was put at ease with the staff involved 👏thanx again 🤒

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

author: Stedd64
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Marvellous Support
body:
Hi there,  
I had or still have a severe mental health diagnosis.  
I liked that no one judged me and there were people listening to me.  
I expect and give punctuality if someone is on leave I expect that the meeting to be cancelled or actually the service user informed if you can not attend it. This has happen multiple times.  
Yes I recommend the following people, Mr Moses, Steve and Solan, and of course Dr Jafar for their dedication and reliability, but also the receptionist's who always been polite and customer focused.  
Mr Moses bubbly and smiling character has always cheered me up and keep me going and his expertise in employment support is marvellous.  
Mr. Steve, has made me aware that people are there to help you just need to reach out and made me realise my achievements as small as their were for me, it were big achievements for my young age of 21. And that a foot in the door is better than none.  
There is no shame in being open about your MH but I do feel that you should not look for a psychologist or a therapist in your friends as they do not have the relevant skills and coping mechanism to deal with your problems. Or try to change them, or grow or to put unreasonable pressure on themselves.  
Life is not always roses and pink but if you keep at it you will overcome any obstacle that comes your way. Be strong and keep at it.  
Thank you for reading!

author: Berry2022
title: Poor hospital discharge arrangements
body:
My mother was assessed as lacking capacity in Feb 2022, and was to be transferred to a care home facility. I, as Power of Attorney, had the welfare powers activated by the onward Consultant confirming ongoing cognitive decline in my mother and that it was appropriate for me to make welfare decisions.  
The nurse on ward 14 declined to pass the Adults with Incapacity Section 47 form to me as they stated this was private and refused to do so. This was despite knowing that I had activated Powers of Attorney, was arranging the Care Home my mother was being admitted to and that I was expected to arrange transport and payment as this was out of area.  
They would not permit me access to the AWI but stated they would send this to the care home manager. My mother was discharged to the care home on a Friday. Her covid vaccination booster injection was due on the following Tuesday at the care home, and because the AWI was incorrect and out of date she was not permitted the vaccine. The nurse had sent the wrong one, from a previous admission in Dec 2021, not one that would cover her treatment in March. If I had been passed this one I could have advised the ward that this was incorrect and had it amended prior to discharge.  
My mother was transferred to a different part of Scotland and therefore required to be registered to a different health board. The AWI was wrong, there was no DNACPR passed over on discharge, and the medications were for one week only, which is very little time considering the relocation and requirements for registering with a new health centre, and health board.  
I have liaised with the new health centre to acquire a new AWI and DNACPR and arrange covid vaccination booster, however this has taken time and has left my mother without the appropriate safeguards in place to ensure appropriate medical treatments.  
Today I have had a review with the person who reviews patients discharged to care homes. When I informed the person of the poor paperwork for discharge they advised that they were not surprised and that about 60% of the people reviewed have similar cases of inept and poor discharge experiences. When asked if they would pass this over to their Team Manager, Service Manager or Head of Service they did not seem inclined to do so.  
I therefore believe that discharge from Ward 14 can be improved, with staff given training in legislation re Powers of Attorney. Also for appropriate AWI/DNACPR and medications for the person to be put in place as routine. Unlike the review person today I find it unacceptable that people discharged from hospital at a time of need are not supported appropriately, and it is disappointing if they feel this is commonplace and not a matter of concern. Inappropriate and poor discharge causes further issues with the person's health,and distress both to them and their families

author: HammondFarm
title: Thank you for the care given to my late Mother
body:
I would like to share our overdue thanks for the care given to our late Mother - Janet. She passed away in the hospital on the evening in January - she was 88 years of age. I think she was in Ward 1 South during her final admission.  
My Mother's health declined quickly late last year to the point that I brought her to A&E beginning December. She was in hospital until end of December when she was discharged to a nursing home. She caught an infection and was readmitted in January until her passing.  
What I would like to highlight is how caring and helpful your staff were during both of these admissions. We would either call for an update on our Mother's situation or your staff would call us. Increasingly it became obvious that it was the final stage of our Mother's life.  
Both nurses and doctors alike gave us the time we needed in all of these calls. We were never hurried and they all gave us their full attention. This may seem simple but it meant lots to us as there were periods when we were unable to visit due to the changing COVID measures.  
We would to pass on our special thanks to the staff in Ward 1 South. In particular to Dr Chris - apologies we don't know his surname. He helped guide us through our Mother's final days with the utmost professionalism, sincerity and thoughtfulness of her needs.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: hawkxd35
title: The staff I saw
body:
I firstly met with the reception staff who were lovely. Big smiles polite and very different from my experience at my GP surgery. Then the 2 lovely ladies who examined me, I can’t thank them enough. They treated me with the upmost respect and were both very professional. I was very anxious but didn’t feel judged in any way.  
A massive thank you to those ladies.  
A very pleasant visit, thank you.

author: tangocf79
title: Having a procedure at Radiology
body:
Arrived for a sensitive procedure today. Booked for next week but I was contacted and offered a cancellation which was gratefully accepted. Referral from GP to Consultant clinic to scan (approximately 5-6 weeks) - incredible!  
Pre-scan literature and information sent well in advance and was easy to follow.  
Arrived before my time and taken immediately. A fantastic well oiled and slick team from start to finish - Paul, Kevin, Lynne & Lynn. Everyone was friendly, professional, knowledgeable, kind, compassionate, funny and above all reassuring.  
I know from chatting to them how busy each day is but despite this, I felt that I was the only person in their care. It was a perfect example of professional and patient centred care. If the team were under pressure with their busy list, they certainly never showed it.  
Thank you all so much and apologies for the veins Paul.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: The staff are lovely here
body:
My son and I came into accident and emergency, it was busy and we had a 5 hour wait to be taken to daisy ward. My son got the nebuliser in accident and emergency as they were not happy with his oxygen levels. I knew it was going to be a wait as I could see 7/8 children in front of us.  
Daisy ward is great, we love the privacy of the rooms and the en-suite.  
The staff are lovely here, they constantly check on my son to make sure he is okay and that he is not too uncomfortable.  
We have not had a bad experience, I am just emotional.  
The only thing is the bed for parents, the pull out sofa really does not cut it if you are staying for longer than one night.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Nothing seems to be a problem for them
body:
Accident and emergency was grand and very straightforward. We were not waiting long at all.  
The staff were so busy and very productive.  
Daisy ward is brilliant, nothing seems to be a problem for them, they get you what you need or want. It is top class and very clean and tidy.  
The staff are excellent, although Clare from last night on this ward and the doctor from accident and emergency went above and beyond.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jo5282
title: Insensitive e-consultation service
body:
I have just used eConsult to request a sick line from my doctor due to having a miscarriage. At the end of the consultation I was asked the standard questions regarding alcohol, smoking, gambling…. and if I could be pregnant or if I’m breastfeeding. Devastated. It’s absolutely unacceptable that this happens. I then tried to contact eConsult directly to complain, but there was no obvious way to do this electronically from their website. Only a phone number, and I am far too upset to speak to someone.  
I have completed their “one time survey” regarding the system multiple times and flagged up that this question should not be asked routinely. For those of us with fertility issues, it is devastating to be asked these questions when you’re trying to request input for something unrelated. There is no consideration for the mental health of people using the system, and the lack of foresight/consideration of psychological factors is shocking.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: julykk99
title: Excellent smooth service
body: Excellent smooth service, Dr Davies was kind and helpful and made a potentially tricky procedure very straightforward.

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Daisy ward is a lovely facility
body:
My son had elective planned surgery and was kept in overnight.  
Daisy ward is a lovely facility, everything is good here and up to date.  
The staff are friendly and my son loves them as they gave him Lego as it is his birthday.  
Noelle, Michelle and Karen were phenomenal I have to say they were always there when needed.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Hospital visit 22
title: Visit to ENT
body:
A big thanks to all the staff that attend me  
Robert Done more than enough to make feel comfortable  
Done very professionally  
Made me feel comfortable

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: RCBH
title: Treatment of dementia patients
body: I was not allowed to wait with my father who has severe dementia while he was waiting to be seen at the Acute Receiving Unit. I asked repeatedly, but was told it was the same rule for everyone which is fair but not everyone is able to advocate for themselves, and a carer with Power of Attorney should be allowed to be present to advocate for their family member.

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Reassurance
body: Excellent level of care and reassurance throughout my hospital stay at the Ulster Hospital Neely Ward. I was kept well informed about decisions about my care. Special mention to Sharon in the Day Procedure Unit and Hannah & Caitlin in the Neely Ward. They made me feel reassured with their levels of care and professionalism, thank you.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: DILLYDONUT
title: Fantastic occupational health service
body:
I would just like to feedback my experience with Maria from Occupational Health who has supported me back to work.  
When I first met with Maria I was in one of the darkest places of my life and had not expected to ever be able to return to my role as an Occupational Therapist or any vocation for that matter. However, with Maria's excellent, compassionate approach, expertise and understanding of mental health, I am now back at work, having taken on a new and exciting role.  
I can honestly say that this would not have been possible without her support. I do not have enough words to express my gratitude to her, so I felt the least I could do was to provide feedback. The Occupational Health service are blessed to have her in their team.

author: sAM2155
title: Wisdom Tooth Extraction
body:
I had an appointment for my wisdom tooth extraction beginning of May however it was within a couple of days of my hen weekend so I phoned spoke to a lovely gentleman in the Orthodontic Reception who was very understanding and kept a note and said he would phone me with any sooner cancellations, true to his word he phoned me back later that day and gave me a date a week earlier which was perfect and would allow me 2 weeks to recover. I was really grateful for this and wanted to say thank you for going above to help me as I know waiting lists for appointments are difficult enough as it is due to covid.  
Although my tooth was more difficult to extract than anticipated Rachel made me feel at ease and was a genuinely lovely person, talking me through everything and making small talk to distract me from the procedure. At all stages of the extraction she made sure I was as comfortable as possible and checked multiple times I wasn't in pain. I would also like to thank Luke who popped through to lend a hand and also the dental nurse who (sorry I cant remember her name) was equally as lovely and caring.  
I just wanted to say thank you to you all as although it wasn't the most pleasant way to spend a bank holiday, everyone I dealt with before hand and on the day really did make the whole experience bearable. Hopefully I wont need any of my other wisdom teeth out but if I do I would be happy to come back and be cared for by any of the team. I think a lot of people think wisdom tooth extraction is horrific so I thought it might be helpful to read a positive experience which may put someone a bit more at ease.  
Thanks again to all the team!

author: puppisfe73
title: Mum was diagnosis
body:
After going to the doctor for blood test, mum was sent to hospital for X-rays, scans and further test.  
Once the results came back we were then told about her cancer.  
We were absolutely devastated, shocked and just couldn’t believe this was happening to her, our whole life’s were turned upside down in the matter off weeks, our hearts were broken and still are, trying to deal with the fact she can not be cured only treated. It felt like we were given blow after blow, day by day. Ed mums cancer specialist has been absolutely fantastic and helped us through it all.

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

author: Grduncan79
title: Fractured wrist
body: Went for day surgery to fix my fractured wrist. All care received was exceptional

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Top Rate Healthcare
body:
- Care needs all met wonderfully  
- Team above excellence  
- 100% Was very very special  
- Everything covered plus great advice  
Top rate + helped me so much, caring, patient 100% wonderful ladies  
Couldn't have had better care and service at this time thank you much both Sophy and Rosie xxx  
God bless you both and keep you safe, sending lots of love.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Wonderful Care
body: Wonderful care give and a pleasure to have the nurses in our home.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

5/5 Care from the north team  
5/5 Very relevant care  
5/5 All care needs were met

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Lovely Team
body: Thank you so much for all the help you have given me. I wish you and your lovely team the best.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Kathas
title: Hospital failure to comply with Disability Discrimination Act
body:
I have spent 2 years at home shielding as I am a double transplant patient with other chronic illnesses & mobility problems. I am also deaf, wear hearing aids & have always tried to cope on my own without help mostly succeeding. Covid has meant face masks, muffled voices & no lip reading. Last year I had an emergency appointment for possible bladder &/or kidney cancer & started on the various investigations. I knew that I would be highly stressed in hospital so I emailed PALS repeatedly to ask what help I could have or for someone to contact. Instead I was directed to the learning disability officers...  
I then had an emergency admission for sepsis. The first few days were difficult as staff refused to make reasonable adjustments for my deafness. I was told off for missing breakfast because I must have misunderstood and should have known. I was told off for asking for a written menu because I couldn't hear menu items listed verbally. I asked for my bed to be labelled with the deaf sign in accordance with the legal NHS Accessible Information standard, 2016, which ensures that all communication needs due to disability are met, this was refused because it was demeaning and would make me vulnerable. I did feed all these problems back to the hospital and got an apology.  
Next I had a kidney biopsy. My previous one had been painful as the anesthesia did not work. I was very nervous of being on a ward close to others after so long isolating. The hospital had forgotten to book my pre op pcr test so I did not even know if the procedure would still go ahead. I had a wasted journey for the non-existent covid test. I was not tested for covid until after being admitted to the ward. My husband had to translate most of the pre-op clerking in questions because I could not understand the nurse. Another nurse kept drawing back the cubicle curtains because he wanted to plug in his computer station and I repeatedly explained to him that I needed them drawn in order to feel calmer.  
The biopsy went ok but afterwards I had to remain flat in bed on the ward for 4 hours to prevent hemorrhaging. During this time my husband was made to sit outside the open ward entrance despite helping me communicate and being my carer. I then looked at my day notes and discovered that there was nothing about my deafness in them despite the proactive emails, my previous hospital stay, complaint and my husband and I verbally explaining to the nurses. Also the deaf sticker that is supposed to be on the notes was missing. When I tried to explain to the nurse what was missing, I was told that deafness was nothing to do with her or the hospital but it was for my GP to deal with. They then moved further away so that I could no longer hear her and refused to discuss this any further.  
I eventually managed to remove my blood pressure cuff despite only partial use and strength of that arm, in an attempt to engage her in further conversation as I knew she would have to explain why she had had done the BP readings every 15 minutes. Instead another nurse came, who was obviously cross with me but I could not understand what she was saying from that distance. I repeatedly begged her to allow my husband back in as I needed his help communicating due to being deaf. This was denied.  
Unbeknown to me my husband had offered to help but was told to go away and security was called. Finally another nurse realised that I might be upset and let my husband in. He manage to calm me down, panic attack reduced when the guards arrived, not wearing masks despite my CEV covid status and anxieties, ripped back the cubicle curtains, stood next to me before leaving. I was terrified, trapped in a corner by staff and guards and not knowing what was going on, there was no way to escape so another panic attack.  
Since then I need sedating for my hospital appointments and before my kidney cancer surgery. My husband has to remain with me for all my appointments. I will not visit anywhere on my own without him, cancel appointments that I think I can etc. I panic at the prospect of dealing with any stranger even on the phone and now refuse to answer it when it rings. I just freeze and hyperventilate until it finally stops.  
Now he needs cancer surgery but I cannot support him in hospital or even visit him and he does not want me to try either. This makes me very, very upset.  
CBT should be starting soon but I do not know if it will help, already maxed out on antidepressants plus diazepam for hospital use.  
The hospital have admitted noncompliance with the NHS AIS but then the hospital manager wrote to me concerning my other complaint about the multiple mistakes and excuses made for not providing the prebiopsy covid screening and I felt used the this opportunity to berate me for being a naughty girl on the day of my biopsy. I do not feel that taking part on the hospital's newly formed Deaf Working Party to discuss improvements will work with the senior manager so hostile. I am prepared to try and work with the hospital to improve things for other people if the senior manager retracts this criticism of me. Telling the staff, patients etc about the AIS with posters, leaflets and information in their website would be a start. This has still not happened after 6 months. No staff have received any training in the AIS since it was introduced in 2016 and the hospital are still non-compliant. My concern is that nothing will be done until they have the perfect computer system to support the AIS rather than incorporating some measures for staff to follow now.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The Care is Second to None
body:
The care could not be improved, it was second to one. The team didn't miss anything.  
All your team are brilliant, caring and answer any questions we have. You all deserve a gold metal and more.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Wonderful Service
body:
I would just like to say thank you to the staff for the wonderful service that I have received. Please would you pass the appreciation on to all staff who cared for me!  
Thank you!

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: They inform you of everything and make sure you understand it
body:
It was my first time coming into accident and emergency. I was so very nervous. As soon as we were in we were taken straight away and were taken up to Daisy Ward within 30 minutes. I was so surprised.  
The daisy ward is very child friendly, and everything is good. They make sure to inform you on everything going on and make sure you understand it. I really do not feel like I am in Daisy Hill hospital.  
The staff are lovely and really nice although I have to admit Shauna and Siobhan went above and beyond. Siobhan was on the ball making sure I was fed and watered, she was going out of her way to make sure I was okay.  
The only thing that needs changed is the communication between doctors. On Monday a different doctor took the abscess, drained it and took pictures and measurements of it. The next day the usual doctor came in and asked us about it and doubted what the other doctor had wrote. It was just concerning they did not agree on things and had told us two different things. We did not know who to believe. All together though we have had a good experience here.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: No Need For Improvement
body:
The quality of my care on the team was 5/5  
The care was completely relevant  
All my care needs were met  
The team provided good care with no need for improvement, they did not miss anything  
thank you

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Alexe98
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Very Impressed
body:
I was very impressed with the care by all.  
Thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Pitlochry Cyclist
title: Very pleased with my treatment
body: My care at the Pitlochry Community Hospital following a cycling accident was exemplary. The staff were friendly and professional throughout and I was extremely well looked after. I was very pleased with how well I was treated.

readBy.name: Perth and Kinross Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Cragma
title: Colonoscopy
body: I was at the Vanguard unit at Hairmyres hospital on Monday for a colonoscopy. This is not the most pleasant procedure but I have to say that everyone of the staff members that dealt with me, made me feel very comfortable and treated with me with great respect ensuring that my dignity was protected at all times. They put me completely at ease and explained everything in a very easy to understand manner. They were very friendly and nothing seemed too much trouble. I cannot praise the team highly enough and want to say a very big thank you for all that you do.

author: LisaMcA
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Cared for and supported
body:
Story by family member of 80+ year old gentleman from Claudy area:  
The Acute Care at home team came at the request of the GP to attend my 95 year old father who is at the end of his life. This has allowed him to be at home, and at all times, Dad and his family have all felt cared for and supported by the professional and helpful team who came to our home and cared for him. Thank you.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: attendantmj83
title: Being looked after well
body:
Once I had been referred by my GP. I was contacted quickly by phone. I had home visits from a nurse from Falls clinic, from an occupational nurse, from a community pharmacist, also a phone call from my surgery pharmacist to discuss changes made. I certainly felt as if I was being looked after, everyone I dealt with was friendly and reflected my opinions.  
Thanks to all.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: WeeJJx
title: You rock Westmarc
body:
I got my new chair today! So many things I can speak about so do bear with me during this little ramble.  
First of all, I was quoted a 12 week wait and only waited 8 before picking the chair up today. Which is absolutely brilliant and i’m really glad that Westmarc are able to hit under the target wait times.  
My chair is a Quickie Argon 2 in Flamingo Glitter. I nearly started sobbing upon seeing it! It was absolutely everything I could ever ask for in a chair. It has a 3 inch camber, foldable push handles, a swing away anti tipper, a static singular footplate and the perfect sized castors (I think 3/4 inches?)  
I felt such a massive difference in my seating position and felt so much more comfortable in this chair. I felt like I was gliding on the ground. I tried it in the little gym hall thingie over the bricks and didn’t feel a single bump. It was so incredibly smooth. The new brakes are brilliant and feel much more stable than my previous chair. It feels like i’m sitting IN the chair, instead of on top of it. It feels as if it’s a part of me instead of an external accessory. And oh my goodness, cannot say thank you enough for the beautiful colour. Who knew a bright pastel pink with ACTUAL glitter would be provided by the NHS?! The colour choices are absolutely amazing and i’m so thankful I got to pick this beautiful colour.  
All in all, I cannot say thank you enough. This chair will (and has already in the hour I’ve had it) changed my life. Not only does it meet all my needs in the technical essence, but it fits my personality and I don’t feel ashamed or embarrassed of my chair. If anything, I want to show the whole world!  
Thank you so much, to the clinicians and reception staff for their mass amount of empathy and kindness towards me and always meeting my energy with my excitement. I don’t think I could’ve done this journey by myself without the amazing support given to me by all the staff at Westmarc. You should be beyond proud of yourselves.  
You rock Westmarc!!

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: The stunt man
title: Surgery involving hip and then knee replacement .
body: My right hip was replaced at Cannock Chase Hospital in December last year and undertaken using general anaesthetic . The surgeon was Mr Bitar and everything was perfect . The left knee was replaced at Cannock Chase Hospital by the same surgeon Mr Bitar in April. This time Epidural Injection was used as anaesthetic . Once again everything was perfect . The technical side of both procedures went perfectly and without any drama .

author: Charlie and cash
title: Truly patient centred care at its best
body:
After losing my sister to suicide I had been struggling with my mental health significantly.  
I returned to work working for the NHS during the pandemic at a particularly stressful time and this only made things worse.  
I cannot thank Gemma at Wishaw locality psychology team for everything you have done for me. After realising I was actually experiencing PTSD I have learned so many coping strategies to help manage this as well as help me through the lowest part of my life.  
Gemma is a kind person who is a credit to her team and the NHS. She listened to me, and she would let me open up whilst giving me the tools to help myself. And that’s the most important thing.  
I think when you are a health professional you never think you will struggle with your health, I struggled to even admit I was struggling. The patience I was shown by Gemma gave me the confidence I needed to acknowledge my feelings and feel them.  
Whilst I do still have some anxiety and low mood this is something I know I can cope with and will improve. Gemma helped me figure out some of the triggers to my PTSD and each therapy session helped me even when there were ups and downs.  
One of the most important things was that I was able to stay in work (whilst also taking some leave) which if I didn’t seek help from psychology I would not have been able to do.  
I cannot thank Gemma enough for all the effort she put in for me. Truly patient centred care at its best.  
My family and me will be forever grateful for that whole team and it doesn’t get said enough, so thank you.

author: slidesm57
title: Treatment from the start has been excellent
body:
In 2008 Dr Down was not happy with the PSA result. A biopsy was arranged at Barnstaple, cancer cells were found, CT & brain scans arranged quickly and carried out. A meeting in Exeter decided on Radiation treatment rather than an operation to remove prostate hormone treatment & radiation to be carried out in Exeter.  
37 trips to Exeter. This was tiring but the radiation staff were excellent. Ongoing monitoring of PSA levels carried out with regular meetings with Dr Martinez or Dr Sheenan. Dr Sheenan was really good more like a friend than doctor  
About 2 years ago my monitoring was taken over by urology dept.  
Recent test shows increase in PSA level.  
Mrs Dring referred to oncology who suggested new scans.  
These have been arranged in the next two weeks.  
I can only say that my treatment from the start has been excellent. The only improvement I could suggest is that it is a pity that there is no bone scanner at Barnstaple. nor can radiation treatment be done there. A train and bus trip to Exeter is more difficult as you get older, especially with prostate problems.

author: handsetnj63
title: Couldn't have been looked after better
body:
I was anxious attending the fracture clinic CAH as it was my first experience, I was meet & greeted by all the team, enquiries how I fracture my left wrist etc  
Jenna & Emma were amazing with me taking their time discussion with the consultant I need a slight alignment of my hand & a lighter plaster applied , the girls were keen I choose a colour to suit my outfit for the Easter Wedding I'm to attending in April I couldn't have been looked after better.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: songthrushyz85
title: Very professional experience
body:
I woke up at the end of March with flashing in my right eye. I contacted the GP surgery and had an appointment at 9:40am. I was seen by paramedic, all neurological observations were normal. I had an eye test and was referred to emergency eye clinic at RCHT. I had a phone call at 1:15pm with an appointment to attend the emergency eye clinic RCHT at 4:00pm.  
I had a triage assessment by a nurse. She introduced herself, both eyes were dilated with drops, tensions were taken - 17 in both eyes, and an eye test was undertaken.  
I had a scan in both eyes. The clinician introduced himself and explained procedure.  
I was seen by the consultant. He explained what the scan revealed, gave me paper information which is most useful. The whole experience was professional, I was treated with dignity and respect. It was a very busy unit but staff were pleasant and patient with everyone there was good collaborative working with all clinicians. Thank you for your excellent care.

author: nuthatchkb85
title: Couldn't have done better
body: Discharge lounge, couldn't have done better caring non judgemental nothing was to much trouble well done and may you get a well deserved rise in pay can't praise you all each and every one of you may the angels watch over you each and every one of you.

author: caringwc87
title: Brought so much into my life
body:
I'm completing this survey for my friend who is a is a wheelchair bound tetraplegic.  
Over the years I, have been very fortunate in regards to my assigned social worker. Overall the attention from the southern trust has veen very good. My present social worker Rachael is, without doubt, carrying on the good work.  
She has a friendly way and is very helpful, I fully appreciate the care and attention I have received over the years, it has brought so much into my life.
